experimentalContext: This causal model represents factors affecting electrochemical performance of disordered rocksalt (DRX) cathode materials for lithium-ion batteries. DRX materials feature a cation-disordered structure with excess lithium, enabling lithium percolation through 0-TM channels. Key performance metrics include discharge capacity (mAh/g), capacity retention over cycling, and rate capability. Performance depends on composition (Li content, redox-active transition metals, charge-compensating metals, fluorine doping), electrochemical test parameters (current density, voltage window), and mechanistic factors (percolation network, short-range order, transition metal migration).

nodes.description: Measured discharge capacity normalized by active material mass (mAh/g). Primary performance metric for battery electrode materials.
Fraction of initial capacity retained after cycling (%). Measures long-term cycling stability and degradation resistance.
Ability to deliver capacity at high current rates. Ratio of capacity at high C-rate to capacity at low C-rate.
Li stoichiometry (x in Lix). Range: 1.0-1.333. Higher Li-excess enables more percolation pathways but requires charge compensation.
Total content of redox-active transition metals (Mn, Cr, V, Fe, Co, Ni). These provide electrochemical capacity via oxidation state changes.
Mn stoichiometry (Mn2+/4+ redox). Primary redox element, earth-abundant, provides stable capacity.
Cr stoichiometry (Cr3+/6+ redox). Enables high-rate capability but prone to TM migration.
V stoichiometry (V3+/5+ redox). Low-voltage redox, prone to TM migration into Li layer.
Total content of charge-compensating transition metals (Ti4+, Zr4+, Nb5+, Mo6+). Stabilize structure and compensate Li-excess charge.
F stoichiometry in oxyfluorides (0-1.333). Lower anion valence accommodates more Li-excess, enhances surface stability, modifies short-range order.
Test current normalized by mass (mA/g). Range: 5-20000 mA/g. Higher currents test kinetic limitations and rate capability.
Upper voltage limit during charging (V). Range: 4.0-5.0V. Higher cutoffs access more capacity but risk electrolyte decomposition and oxygen loss.
Lower voltage limit during discharge (V). Range: 1.0-2.5V. Lower cutoffs access more capacity but may cause irreversible structural changes.
Number of charge-discharge cycles (1-891). More cycles reveal long-term degradation mechanisms.
Connectivity of 0-TM (zero transition metal) channels for Li diffusion. Requires sufficient Li-excess (typically >1.09) to form percolating network.
Local cation ordering in the disordered structure. Affects Li diffusion barriers and percolation pathway tortuosity.
Capacity contribution from transition metal oxidation/reduction. Depends on TM content and accessible oxidation states.
Anionic redox contribution from O2-/O- oxidation at high voltages. Provides extra capacity but can cause O2 loss and structural degradation.
Movement of transition metal ions into Li layer during cycling. Blocks Li diffusion pathways, causes voltage fade and capacity loss.
Resistance to irreversible structural changes during cycling. Affected by TM migration, oxygen loss, and Li/vacancy ordering.
Resistance to electrolyte decomposition at electrode surface. Compromised at high voltages (>4.5V) causing SEI growth and impedance rise.
Electroneutrality constraint requiring compensation for Li-excess. Met by high-valent inert TMs (Ti4+, Nb5+) or F substitution.
